Award.AbstractNarration:
ACM MobiSys conference is the leading international conference on mobile computing systems and wireless networking platforms. It invites research contributions addressing the challenges in the area of mobile computing and wireless networks, from the perspective of wireless and mobile systems, platforms and applications. The conference features a high-quality technical program, with an acceptance rate of around 10% out of around 250 submissions. It has a single-track session, which offers significant opportunities for individual and small groups that foster technical and social interactions among a diverse set of participants. MobiSys is also an international conference that stimulates exchanges between various international research communities.

This award will help increase the representation and participation of United States-based students at the conference by providing 25 or more travel grants limited to a maximum of $750 each. By creating new opportunities for graduate students, especially those from under-represented groups, to attend a high-quality conference, this award will benefit the students by giving them an opportunity to interact with world-class researchers, inspire them to try new research directions, providing mentoring opportunities, as well as the chance to seek out internships and post-doctoral positions which will help the students advance in their research career.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Funds were requested to support students at U.S. institutions to attend the 12th Annual International Conference on Mobile Systems, Applications, and Services (MobiSys 2014). MobiSys, sponsored by ACM SIGMOBILE, as held June 16th-19th, 2014 in Bretton Woods, new Hampshire. Priority was given to students who would benefit from attending this conference, but were unlikely to attend due to the unavailability of travel funding. In addition, we encouraged applications from female and underrepresented groups in higher education.

We broadcasted the student travel advertisement to all the relevant ACM and IEEE mailing lists. The MobiSys conference listed all the details of the travel scholarship in its webpage. 

Through a selection process which included letters of recommendation from PhD advisors and personal statements from the candidates, we selected 27 students. The 27 students represented 27 unique academic institutions from 18 different states. 25% of those students were female. 

  Intellectual Merit: The intellectual merit of this proposal resided in the contributions that the student participants would make to (1) the MobiSys 2014 event (premier conference in their respective mobile computing and system integration fields) and (2) the future scientific progress of the student’s research. In addition to the technical paper presentations, MobiSys 2014 offers a wide variety of technical activities (e.g., keynote presentations, poster session, demos, three workshops, and PhD Forum). The exposure to the technical content of MobiSys 2014 would inspire students to address the tough problems in their respective field, with a long-term benefit of scientific progress for these types of networks.

 Broader Impact: The broader impact of this proposal concerned the development of the graduate students that were able to attend MobiSys 2014 due to the provided travel support. In particular, we encouraged applications from groups underrepresented in higher education. The requested travel funds allowed graduate students conducting research in the field to attend high-caliber technical presentations, be exposed to state-of-the-art research, and interact with leading researchers and fellow graduate students. We expect the impact to the students’ careers from attending MobiSys 2014 to be substantial.
